question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: Who was Kang-Mi Pang's employer in 2020?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
Here is a narrative that weaves in detailed evidence to support the claim that Kang-Mi Pang worked for Seoul National University Dental Hospital:

Title: The Unwavering Commitment of Kang-Mi Pang

In the bustling city of Seoul, South Korea, a beacon of hope shines bright in the world of dentistry - Seoul National University Dental Hospital. For decades, this esteemed institution has been at the forefront of oral healthcare, attracting talented professionals from far and wide. One such individual is Kang-Mi Pang, a dedicated researcher whose tireless efforts have contributed significantly to the hospital's reputation for excellence. Kang-Mi Pang's journey with Seoul National University Dental Hospital began on a crisp autumn morning in 2015. Fresh from completing her Ph.D. in Dental Science, Pang was eager to apply her knowledge in a real-world setting. Her passion for research and commitment to improving patient outcomes caught the attention of the hospital's administration, who offered her a position as a researcher in the Department of Oral Biology. As Pang settled into her new role, she quickly became an integral part of the hospital's research team. Her expertise in molecular biology and biochemistry proved invaluable in the development of novel treatments for oral diseases. Colleagues and mentors alike praised her meticulous attention to detail, innovative approach to problem-solving, and unwavering dedication to her craft. One of Pang's most notable contributions during her tenure at Seoul National University Dental Hospital was her work on a groundbreaking study investigating the role of stem cells in periodontal regeneration. Published in the prestigious Journal of Dental Research, the study's findings shed new light on the potential for stem cell-based therapies to revolutionize the treatment of periodontal disease. Pang's co-authorship on this paper not only showcased her expertise but also solidified her position as a rising star in the field of dental research. In addition to her research endeavors, Pang was an active participant in the hospital's academic programs, regularly lecturing and mentoring students in the Doctor of Dental Surgery (DDS) program. Her ability to distill complex concepts into engaging, easy-to-understand lectures earned her high praise from students and faculty alike. Her commitment to education extended beyond the classroom, as she also developed and led workshops on evidence-based dentistry, further enriching the hospital's educational offerings. As the years passed, Pang's reputation as a leading researcher and educator continued to grow.
content.source_2: In the year 2027, the bustling streets of New York City were abuzz with the latest advancements in medical technology. Amidst the towering skyscrapers and neon-lit billboards, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center stood as a beacon of hope for those fighting the devastating disease. It was here, within the esteemed institution's walls, that Dr. Kang-Mi Pang dedicated her life's work to unraveling the mysteries of cancer. As a leading researcher in the field, Dr. Pang had spent years honing her expertise in the intricacies of cellular biology and genetic engineering. Her groundbreaking research had already yielded promising results, and her name was whispered in reverence among her peers. But it was in 2027 that her work would take a quantum leap forward. That summer, Dr. Pang was part of a team that made a revolutionary discovery – a novel gene therapy that could selectively target and eradicate cancer cells while leaving healthy tissue intact. The implications were staggering, and the medical community held its collective breath as the team began human trials. Dr. Pang's days blurred into nights as she worked tirelessly to refine the treatment, pouring over data and collaborating with her colleagues to overcome the inevitable setbacks. Her office, nestled in the heart of MSKCC, became a sanctuary of sorts, lined with stacks of research papers, diagrams, and half-empty coffee cups. As the months passed, the results began to trickle in. Patients who had been given mere months to live were now experiencing unprecedented remissions. The news spread like wildfire, and Dr. Pang found herself at the forefront of a medical revolution. In the midst of this whirlwind, Dr. Pang's personal life became a casualty of her all-consuming passion. Her relationships suffered, and her friends and family grew concerned about her well-being. But she couldn't help it – she was driven by a singular focus, a burning desire to vanquish the disease that had claimed so many lives. As the year drew to a close, Dr. Pang's team made another breakthrough, this time developing a diagnostic tool that could detect cancer in its earliest stages. The possibilities were endless, and Dr. Pang knew that her work would change the face of medicine forever. In 2027, Dr. Kang-Mi Pang's name became synonymous with hope, her research a testament to the power of human ingenuity and determination. As she looked out over the glittering Manhattan skyline, she knew that she had only just begun to scratch the surface of what was possible.
